subject: Economics
title: Two-Sided Markets: Why Uber Loses Money and Doesn't Care
description: Learn Two-Sided Markets: Why Uber Loses Money and Doesn't Care in one minute.

hook.text: Uber lost $31 billion in its first decade. Investors kept funding it.

buildup.text: Two-sided markets connect two groups: riders and drivers, buyers and sellers, developers and users.

discovery.text: The chicken-and-egg problem: riders won't join without drivers; drivers won't join without riders.

twist.text: Once both sides are locked in, the platform raises prices and cuts subsidies.

climax.text: Two-sided markets naturally tip toward monopoly. Once one platform has both sides, switching costs trap everyone.

punchline.text: When a company loses billions to gain customers, it's not being generous.

quiz.question: Why did Uber subsidize rides at a loss for years?
options: To solve the chicken-and-egg problem and capture both sides of the market before raising prices
They never planned to make money
